Based on the search results, I can provide comprehensive information about the real-life inspirations behind Charlotte Brontë's "Jane Eyre," particularly regarding Lowood School, Cowan Bridge, Rochester, and Thornfield Hall.

## Lowood School and Cowan Bridge

Lowood School in Jane Eyre was directly inspired by the Clergy Daughters' School at Cowan Bridge in Lancashire, which Charlotte Brontë and her sisters attended as pupils. The deaths of Charlotte Brontë's sisters, Elizabeth and Maria, who died of tuberculosis (consumption) in childhood as a result of the conditions at their school, recalls Helen Burns's death from tuberculosis in the novel.

Mr. Brocklehurst, the harsh evangelical minister who runs Lowood, is based on Rev. William Carus Wilson (1791–1859), the Evangelical minister who ran the Cowan Bridge school. Fellow pupils from Cowan Bridge recognized the school from Jane Eyre and also some of the teachers.

## Helen Burns and Maria Brontë

Helen Burns is based on Charlotte's eldest sister, Maria, who also died of consumption. Elizabeth Gaskell wrote: "I need hardly say, that Helen Burns is as exact a transcript of Maria Brontë as Charlotte's wonderful power of reproducing character could give". Charlotte Brontë's "imagination built up two strongly contrasted ideas—one, as Maria as the epitome of goodness; the other, of Cowan Bridge as the epitome of evil".

## Thornfield Hall Inspirations

Thornfield Hall may be modeled on two different manor houses with which Brontë was familiar. The first, called Norton Conyers, is near the city of Ripon in North Yorkshire. North Lees Hall, a large, forbidding-looking stone manor house in Derbyshire, also seems to fit the description of Thornfield. In 1846 Brontë spent three weeks in the village of Heathersage, in Derbyshire, visiting her old school friend Ellen Nussey.

## Other Personal Inspirations

John Reed's decline into alcoholism and dissolution recalls the life of Charlotte's brother Branwell, who became an opium and alcohol addict in the years preceding his death. Finally, like Jane, Charlotte became a governess.

Many scholars agree that when Charlotte Brontë wrote Jane Eyre, she based many of the situations and characters in the book on her own experiences and acquaintances. Brontë declared, "I will show you a heroine as plain and as small as myself," in regards to creating Jane Eyre.

The novel draws extensively from Charlotte Brontë's personal experiences, transforming her tragic family history and educational experiences into one of literature's most enduring works.
